brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a rule in JetBrains Inspectopedia that reports invalid transactional lifecycle method declarations in Spring testing classes. These methods are annotated with @BeforeTransaction and @AfterTransaction in classes annotated as @Transactional. The rule states that these annotated methods must have no arguments and no return type.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'invalid-transactional-lifecycle-method-declaration' checks all classes in the project. If a class is annotated with '@Transactional', it checks all methods in that class. If a method is annotated with either '@BeforeTransaction' or '@AfterTransaction', it asserts that the method has no arguments (using the 'isEmpty' function on the method's arguments) and that the return type of the method is 'void'. If these conditions are not met, it reports an error message indicating the invalid transactional lifecycle method declaration, specifying the method name and the fully qualified name of the class.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule appears to be syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions provided, and does not introduce any new functions. The rule logic seems to correctly implement the requirement of checking for invalid transactional lifecycle method declarations in Spring testing classes.
